GOVERNMENT CHINESE
SECONDARY IV EXAMINATION
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is my pleasure to inform hon. Members that after the motion* was carried by a majority vote at 11.45 p.m. last night, first condemning the pickets for their unreasonable action, and, second, sanctioning police protection for students who wish to take their examinations and for their parents who accompany them, there were no more pickets today in any of the examination centres. A total of 628 students took supplementary papers today for the second compulsory paper of the examination in Elementary Mathematics, making the total number of students who have taken the examinations 2,145 so far, i.e., 68 per cent.
*The motion reads as follows:

    That this House condemns the actions of the picketers in obstructing, intimidating or otherwise forcefully preventing students from taking their examinations, and in response to an appeal from parents of students who wish to take these examinations that they and their children should be offered Police protection, hereby resolves that this House approves of any action according to law by the Government through the Police to protect students wishing to take their examinations to ensure that they are not intimidated or injured, and that the students and their parents who accompany them are given free passage and access into and out of all examination halls.

MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


2.33 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November,1961],

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya.".-(The Minister for Labour- Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim).

    Which Amendment was,

    'To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth State and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens on Merger Day".' -(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

2.35 p.m.

    Mr Wong Soon Fong (Toa Payoh)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will continue my speech made last Friday. Unfortunately, this debate on an important question - merger - has been interrupted unnecessarily by -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not think the hon. Member is justified in saying that the debate has been interrupted unnecessarily. It was quite an important motion that was debated the whole of yesterday.

    Mr Wong Soon Fong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, what I mean to say is this, that this question of merger is very important and should be clearly decided upon so as to show what kind of phoney merger the P.A.P. is trying to bring about to the people. We in the Barisan Sosialis, especially the Member for Queenstown, have indicated at the time of moving the amendment that the Prime Minister has already been exposed in bringing about a phoney merger. Several questions were raised but there was no reply whatsoever from the Government.

    The question of citizenship after merger and the significance of the so-called nationality have so far not been properly clarified by the Prime Minister to the people of Singapore. Furthermore, there has been a great deal of unnecessary issues and side issues on the nationality and citizenship problems to confuse the vision of the people. It was reported in the leading newspapers of this country - the Sin Chew Jit Poh and the Nanyang Siang Pau - on the 26th and 27th of November that the State Advocate-General had stated the distinction between "citizenship" and "nationality". The State Advocate-General said that according to the merger proposed by the Prime Minister, the present citizens of Singapore and those in the Federation would be equally considered as nationals of the new Federation on Merger Day. That is to say, they will enjoy equal rights and privileges on Merger Day and will thereafter shoulder equal obligations and responsibilities without any distinction

at all. Mr Speaker, Sir, the S.A.G.'s explanation of nationality is correct. We can see that this question of nationality has a meaning only as far as foreign countries are concerned, but from the newspaper report of the 26th November, we also read a statement issued by the Prime Minister's Office pinpointing the opinion given by the S.A.G. In this statement, it is stated that whether a person is called a Federation national or citizen, he has no addition to or subtraction of his rights. What is the meaning of the statement issued by the Prime Minister's Office? I think it is nothing but to confuse the views of the people in regard to nationality and citizenship. If this merger arrangement materialises, I would like to know whether the local citizens in Singapore would be able to have a common political life with those in the Federation. Would it also mean that according to the merger arrangement made by the Prime Minister, the unemployed citizens in Singapore would be able to get employment in the Federation? There is another question, that is, after merger, will the Federation Government treat Singapore citizens without any discrimination whatsoever? From this Statement issued by the Prime Minister's Office, we can see that a citizen is usually considered to be a person enjoying certain rights within his own country, and the question of nationality is only applicable to the status of a person in the international field. So from this paragraph we can see clearly that the so-called nationality is only applicable to foreign countries, and this so-called equal status of citizens is only applicable to our own country alone. Therefore, we can see that there is a distinction between citizenship and nationality. This distinction is not inexplicable. Then why should the Prime Minister have to give radio talks and press conferences on several occasions regarding this question? In spite of all talks by the Prime Minister, the people of Singapore have not understood what he is trying to drive at. So it is obvious that our Prime Minister is not being frank and honest. He is afraid that the people will easily discover that

Column: 1291

his merger is a phoney one. Whenever the Prime Minister has occasion to talk about citizenship and nationality, he usually tries to be very evasive and talks about unimportant things in order to cover up his phoney merger which is a sell-out. As a result of this, he has had to give directions to the State Advocate-General to prepare a statement in regard to the nationality and citizenship questions.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the phoney merger arrangement made by the Prime Minister will bring about three different classes of citizens. The first are those Federal citizens who have absolute control in the Parliament. The second are those Singapore citizens who are eligible to elect representatives to the Central Parliament in the Federation. The third are those citizens not born in Singapore and are not eligible to apply for Federal citizenship. This last type of citizens will not be able to take part in national affairs although they have to carry out whatever resolutions are passed by the Central Parliament.

    Therefore, according to the phoney merger of the Prime Minister, we can see that there is no true merger or a reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya. As a matter of fact, our Prime Minister is trying to come to a compromise with the Federation to sell out Singapore.

    The P.A.P. leadership realise the expansion of the Left-wing forces in both Singapore and the Federation. In Singapore especially, the new socialist forces have become quite formidable, so that the P.A.P. leadership have now to resort to mean methods to save themselves from their precarious position. They try to get the support of the S.P.A. in this House. They, want to co-operate with a Right-wing figure, namely, the Member for Cairnhill, so that they can stand together. During the debate in this House, they have expressed almost the same views. From this, it is very clear that the P.A.P. is going to the Right. Outside this Assembly, they are making use of the radio and the newspapers to disseminate fear by branding some persons as Communists in order that the people will not have the guts to go against them. They are trying to distract the attention of the people so that they can bring about their phoney merger which is a sell-out of the interests of the people of Singapore. So they are trying to save themselves at the expense of others. The P.A.P. leadership have even gone to the extent of splitting unions and brought politics into the unions. They are trying to create suspicion among the races. They are trying to gain the support of the English-educated so that they can perpetuate their divide-and-rule policy. autonomy forever? Or is this a question yet to be answered by the Central Government, as it is the supreme authority in deciding policies?

    One quarter of the revenue of Singapore, namely, $90 million, has got to be paid to the Federal Parliament. And in order to cover up the deficit, the Government here may have to increase taxes. In the end, the lives of the people of Singapore will be more difficult.

    The third point is that we want to have a true merger. We in the Barisan Sosialis endorse true merger, so that Singapore citizens will be able to become automatically Federal citizens and so that representatives can be elected from among Singapore citizens, the number to be in proportion to the number of its citizens. Singapore citizens will be able to stand for election on a national basis, including election to the Federal Parliament and the State Assembly. In this way, there will be a strong force from the representatives of the people of Singapore, and we will be able to amend unreasonable legislation. In this way also, workers, farmers, businessmen and the produce of Singapore citizens will be enjoying a better life because they have Federal citizenship. And in this way too, the peoples of the two territories will be able to enjoy common citizenship rights and lead a common political life.

    Finally, we want to distinguish between the advantages and disadvantages of merger. We must ascertain the opinion of the people whether merger is advantageous or disadvantageous, and what kind of merger we must have. This question should be decided by the one man one vote method. Who should represent the people of Singapore in the talks on merger between the Federation and Singapore? Well, we can have a general election to answer this question.

    Therefore, I am in full support of the amendment tabled by our Party Chairman, who is the Member for Queenstown. In this amendment, we want to seek a genuine merger.

3.09 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Chor Yeok Eng)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Assembly has been debating for over two weeks the question of supporting in principle the merger of the two territories, and the amendment moved by the Member for Queenstown. I do not want to waste any more time of the Assembly over the same question, as my colleagues have replied to the criticisms by the Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen. But there are several points which I feel I must bring out for emphasis. These points have already been emphasised by several Assemblymen in this House. What are these?

    Since the debate began, several speakers have stressed that the interests of the people must come first, that we must always listen to the people, and that the interests of the Party should come next. This is correct, of course. My colleagues and I entirely agree with this point. And because of this, the present political situation in Singapore has come about. Mr Speaker, Sir, let me say this: if we are not carrying on in the interests of the people, then our Party will be broken up. But we are acting in the interests of the people and trying to fulfil our promises to them. Therefore, we are not worried about the activities of the opponent political Parties. This is the essence of democracy.

    Since the question of merger was raised, the public and newspaper editorials have given their opinions. They have all said that it is inevitable that there will finally be merger. It is only a question of time. The coming of merger is just like the sun rising from the east, and the water flowing into the sea. This is a natural course, and is also a natural law. Nobody can change this course. If anybody wants to cover up this truth by tactics and manoeuvring, he is only ignoring the tide of the present era, which is impossible. I have already pointed out that all this is

Column: 1298

natural law. And so as the sun will, of course, rise from the east, it will set when the time comes. That cannot be changed.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, since many Assemblymen have already emphasised the importance of the livelihood of the people, may I stress further by asking whether merger between Singapore and the Federation of Malaya is also one of the questions relating to the livelihood of the people of Singapore? In my opinion, it is so. It concerns very much the livelihood of the people. The Assemblymen of the Barisan Sosialis have talked about many things, amongst them, socialism. May I say that in my view, as Singapore is a small island of 225 square miles and without natural resources, it will find it difficult to realise socialism by itself? That is why we have to seek a merger of the two territories in order to realise socialism. After the reunification of the two territories, socialism can be achieved in Singapore. Otherwise, all talks and plans are only mere words on paper, and are without any effect. The population of Singapore keeps on increasing. Can all these talks help to solve the acute problems facing us today in Singapore? We feel we cannot achieve certain aims or realise certain objectives by just delivering empty talks or writing thesis. We can only achieve our objectives through concrete work and practical planning.

    I want to point out further that it is because we stress the importance of placing the interest of the people above the interest of the Party that we are not willing to do the things that the Members of the Barisan Sosialis have done. They are acting like clowns in their attempt to confuse the vision of the people.

I want, to reply to the charges they have levelled against us. My colleagues have already given their replies to some of them and there is no need for me to repeat them. But I feel it is necessary for me to point out some of the other

charges. In the course of the debate during these few days, they have repeatedly accused us of selling out the rights of the people of Singapore by this merger. Let us define the words "sell-out". We recognise the fact that the people of Singapore and the people of the Federation of Malaya are brothers. They have been separated for 16 years by artificial means. How can this reunification be considered as a kind of sell-out? To sell out means to sell what belongs to us to someone else. But since the Federation of Malaya is our sister State, how can we say that we are selling ourselves to the Federation of Malaya? Since the people of the Federation of Malaya are like our brothers, we are of the same family. Therefore, now is the time for us to unite together. How can an act which brings about the reunification of the two territories be termed as a sell-out? I hope other Assemblymen in this House will give a further definition of the word "sell-out".

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I want to reiterate that at the inauguration of our Party sometime ago, the reunification of the two territories was one of our objectives. We have been working hard since then to realise this objective. In other words, we have been working hard to fulfil the hope of the people of Singapore. This is also the fulfilment of one of our promises to the people. The people elected us to this Assembly in the hope that we can bring about a better life for them. As representatives of the people, we have to respect their views, wishes and hopes. But when we respect the views and wishes of the people by acting accordingly, our friends in the Barisan Sosialis accuse us of turning Right. If this is their kind of logic, then I think the definition of words in the dictionary should be changed.

    In these few days, Assemblymen of the Barisan Sosialis have incessantly accused us of trying to push through this merger in order to safeguard our political position. My colleagues and I can say here categorically that we do not form the Government just for our own benefit. We have been conducting
